channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report E-2024030519
item.description:
Report E-2024030519

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-28T15:13:06+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-12
  • City: BASTROP
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: OCCIDENTAL CHEMICAL CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At approximately 8:30 am, a OxyChem truck driver was delivering Caustic Soda to a customer site (Morehouse BioEnergy) located in Bastrop, LA. The driver met with the customer site operator, completed the “In the Interest of Safety Form” (which is a form utilized by OxyChem truck drivers to ensure that enough space exists in a customer tank prior to unloading), hooked up offloading hoses, and began offloading. Near the end of the offloading process, product began to overflow from the customer's storage tank into the containment area. The OxyChem truck driver immediately shut down the offloading process. The customer site operator was present with the driver when the overflow occurred and made a comment that they would have to check the tank level indicator for accuracy because the calculation during the completion of the “In the Interest of Safety Form” showed that there was sufficient capacity available within the storage tank. Customer site personnel washed down the area. The spill was estimated to be approximately 75-gallons. No injuries, property damage, or environmental impact as a result of the incident.

item.title: Report E-2024030494
item.description:
Report E-2024030494

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-28T15:13:06+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-15
  • City: JERSEY CITY
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: First Call Environmental was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted an 8ft-by-3ft area of the asphalt lot and two (2) areas of the trailer floor measuring 8ft-by-15ft and 8ft-by-4ft and estimated that twenty-five (25) gallons of material was released due to forklift damaging one (1) 275-gallon poly tote. First Call Environmental personnel neutralized the impacted areas and the impacted wooden pallet and used absorbents to collect the material. The wooded pallet was broken down and placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The impacted absorbents were recovered and containerized into two (2) 55- gallon poly drums. The remaining product in the damaged poly tote was transferred to a new tote and the damaged tote was cut up and placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-28T15:13:06+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-25
  • City: OREM
  • State: UT
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: RESPONDED TO (2) PACKAGES THAT WERE COLD TO THE TOUCH. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED APPROXIMATELY TWO POUNDS OF DRY ICE COOLING MEAT PRODUCTS. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOXES TO INDICATE DRY ICE WAS BEING SHIPPED IN THE AIR NETWORK. ADDITIONAL TRACKING NUMBER TO ANOTHER CONSIGNEE IN THE USA IS 1Z85E85Y0217815894. THE OUTER BOXES ARE PREPRINTED WITH ORIENTATION ARROWS AND PERISHABLE. THESE PACKAGES HAVE NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SEVICE CO. THESE PACKAGES WERE SHIPPED FROM UTAH USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER 85E85Y, WASATCH WAGYU, 30661 OLD LINCOLN HWY, COALVILLE UT 84017-9611.

item.title: Report E-2024030490
item.description:
Report E-2024030490

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-27T15:12:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-08
  • City: Sedalia
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: AUTOZONE TEXAS, L.P.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 8, 2024 at 5:36am, an AutoZone tractor trailer had the trailer tires go onto a rain softened shoulder causing the tractor trailer to jack knife and ultimately rollover onto the passenger side of the vehicle. During the rollover, the last pallet on the driver side of the trailer (with an electric pallet jack under it) fell on the last pallet on the passenger side of the trailer that contained 24 automotive batteries. The weight of the pallet and pallet jack cracked the plastic case of 10-12 of the batteries releasing approximately 1.2 gal. of battery acid (sulfuric acid) per battery. The acid did start leaking from the trailer until after the tractor and trailer were uprighted were in the process of returning to the roadway. The plastic wrapped pallet containing the batteries contained the leak until the pallet was returned to the upright position and then the acid began leaking through the pallet. The onsite towing company had a response team come and contain the spill, dispose of the damaged batteries and remediate the affected soil.

item.title: Report X-2024030551
item.description:
Report X-2024030551

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-27T15:12:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-05
  • City: BATON ROUGE
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 03-05-2024 a CN transportation employee observed liquid running down the side of tank car from the top # UTLX 668009 at the CN Baton Rouge Yard located in Baton Rouge, LA. The employee reported the observation to the Transportation Manager who in turn initiated an emergency response from the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The on duty Dangerous Goods Officer dispatched an emergency response contractor to the yard to investigate. The responding contractor's initial observation found product residue on both sides of the tank car. Further assessment revealed that all (6) manway cover swing bolts were less than tool tight (could turn by hand) with (1) of the swing bolts in the down position causing a leak from the manway cover due to an improper seal of the gasket. The shipper security seal was found to be intact. The shipper manway cover security seal was removed and the cover was opened for the purpose of replacing the gasket. The manway cover swing bolts were then tightened in a star pattern utilizing an 18" pipe wrench. The tank car was then moved to an accessible track for the purpose of exterior cleaning.

  • Description: On 03/20/2024, at 0712, personnel in the CSXT Lafayette Yard reported CTCX731986, a loaded tank car of Alcohols, N.O.S. (Denatured Fuel Ethanol), leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper Poet Bioprocessing, was contact via PERS (Report #02787. RMS, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found 1 of 6 manway cover bolts less than tool tight. RMS personnel properly secured the manway cover and stopped the release. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Sierra Torr (765-712-1696, sierra.torr@poet.com). The car was released for transportation.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XKC experienced a UN3266 Flash Clene 1414 release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5 cup of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the poly tote body due to a crack on the top corner of the tote. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with absorbents, pads, and PPE into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOXES TO INDICATE DRY ICE WAS BEING SHIPPED IN THE AIR NETWORK. ADDITIONAL TRACKING NUMBER TO ANOTHER CONSIGNEE IN THE USA IS 1Z85E85Y0232506412. THE OUTER BOXES ARE PREPRINTED AS PERISHABLE WITH ORIENTATION ARROWS. THESE PACKAGES HAVE NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO. THESE PACKAGES WERE SHIPPED FROM UTAH USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER 85E85Y, WASATCH WAGYU, 30661 OLD LINCOLN HWY, COALVILLE UT 84017-9611.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was being transported by cart from trailer to van line. During transport, the cart turned and the box fell from the cart, landing upside down. Upon seeing leakage, package was reoriented right side up, then transferred into a postage container. DescribePack: 2 of the 4 bottles leaked via the caps, appearing visually less full than the others. The caps on the leaking bottles feel rough to twist and are slightly misaligned to the bottles. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Majority of the leakage was absorbed by the external box itself, ruining it in the process. Bottles were removed from box and placed inside a postage bin along with the failed box. Neutralizing agent powder was spread on the spill site.

THERE IS ONE CAN OF TURBO DOKHA AIR PIPE CLEANER X 150 ML, CONTENTS COMPRESSED GAS LIQUID 99.9% TETRAFLUOROETHANE, CAS NO 811-97-2. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER SHIPPING POLY BAG MAILER. THE PACKAGE WAS FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT PRIOR TO THE DISCOVERY OF THE UNDECLARED CONTENTS. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM UNITED ARAB EMIRATES USING UPS ACCOUNT 84YY56, SMSA EXPRESS TRANSPORTATION LLC, P.O. BOX 36670, DUBAI, UNITED ARAB EMIRATES.

item.title: Report E-2024030433
item.description:
Report E-2024030433

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-25T15:12:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-14
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 14, 2024, two (2) 55-gallon drums of UN3098 were punctured by a forklift and released approximately twenty (20) gallons of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews utilized duct tape to patch the damaged drums to prevent additional release. TLE crews collected and containerized the damaged drums into two (2) 95-gallon overpack drums for disposal purposes. Soda ash was deployed worked in with hand tools. A granular absorbent and a degreasing agent were deployed and worked in with hand tools. All undamaged cargo was wiped with absorbent pads to remove any residual product and repalletized for continued processing and shipping. All impacted materials were collected and containerized in one (1) 35-gallon drum for disposal purposes. Soda ash was deployed to neutralize the impacted outside the concrete ground and worked in with hand tools. All impacted materials were collected and containerized in one (1) additional 35-gallon drum for disposal purposes.

IN THE DMP, OPENED THE BOX TO BEGIN WORKING ON THE LEAKING TO DISCOVER THE PRODUCT WITH A CORROSIVE DIAMOND LABEL ON IT. IMMEDIATELY STOPPED, AND NOTIFIED RMP, WHO IN TURN NOTIFIED THE CHSP. AFTER CALLING THE UNDECLARED HOTLINE, GOT PERMISSION TO PROCESS THE CORROSIVE MATERIAL. THE OUTSIDE CARTON HAD NO HAZMAT INDICATIONS ON IT. THE INTERIOR OF THE CARTON THE HAZMAT WAS IN A CLEAR PLASTIC BAG WITH ANOTHER ITEM, CORROSIVE LIQUIDS, N.O.S. THERE WAS ONLY THREE AIR BAGS OF PACKING MATERIAL IN THE BOX AS WELL.

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XLA experienced a UN3085 Kolene No. 5 release from a 500-pound supersack. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2 pounds of product released to a 2’ x 2’ area of the wooden trailer floor and a 15’ x 2’ area of the concrete dock floor. The supersack was ripped due to improper loading. The material was transferred from the damaged sack into a 55-gallon poly drum for shipment on. All released product was placed into a second 55-gallon poly drum and the damaged sack and pads were placed into a third 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

Report X-2024030992

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-25T15:12:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-15
  • City: EARTH CITY
  • State: MO

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A FULLY LABELED HAZMAT PACKAGE THAT APPEARED TO BE LEAKING WAS DISCOVERED BY AN UNLOADER IN THE TRAILER ON BAY 51. THE UNLOADER LEFT THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR. WITHIN 5 MINUTES A DMP RESPONDER ARRIVED DONNING THE CORRECT PPE AND USING THE APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET, DETERMINED THAT THE PACKAGE COULD BE SAFELY TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION IT WAS REVEALED THAT THE CAP ON ONE OF THE INNER PLASTIC CONTAINERS WAS CRACKED AND LOOSE BY 1/6 OF A TURN, RESULTING IN TWO OUNCES OF LIQUID LEAKING OUT ONTO THE OUTER CARTON. THERE WAS NO PACKING MATERIAL.

  • Description: AT THE UPS WORLDPORT FACILITY IN LOUISVILLE, KENTUCKY, WE RESPONDED TO AN AIR PACKAGE THAT NEEDED TO BE REWRAPPED. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED TWO INNER BOXES MARKED 9MM 147GR RN LOW RECOIL (900 FPS) 500 ROUNDS. THESE INNER BOXES CONTAINED LOOSE AMMUNITION WITH SOME POKING THROUGH ONE SIDE OF THE INNER BOXES. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX TO INDICATE AMMUNITION WAS BEING SHIPPED. THE PACKAGE HAD PREVIOUSLY FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT FROM ATL TO SDF PRIOR TO THE DISCOVERY.

  • Description: On March 13, 2024, one (!) 275-gallon tote of UN3266 was punctured in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and debris were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums. FCE personnel transferred the product from damaged tote into a new one to be shipped off to its destination.

  • Description: AT 20:00 WHILE PERFORMING A HAZMAT AUDIT ON A PACKAGE CAR UPS HAZMAT AUDITOR PULLED AN UN MARKED BOX AND OPENED THE PACKING SLIP LOCATED ON THE OUTSIDE OF THE BOX. SHE THEN LOOKED UP THE SDS FOR THE PRODUCT LISTED ON THE PACKING SLIP AND NOTICED IT SAID THE ITEM WAS REGULATED FOR TRANSPORTATION. SHE THEN CALLED THE HAZMAT SUPPORT CENTER WHO INSTRUCTED HER TO OPEN THE BOX TO CONFIRM THE CONTENTS. THE CONTENTS WERE CONFIRMED AND THE HAZMAT SUPPORT CENTER SAID THE BOX WAS A SUSPECTED UNDECLARED HAZMAT AND TO GIVE IT TO A DESIGNATED RESPONDER.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 18, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon jug of UN1760 was missing a lid and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES deployed neutralizing, granular absorbents to the released product and swept them up with hand tools. One (1) 55-gallon drum that contained the one (1) impacted 5-gallon jug, and one (1) 5-gallon bucket that contained the impacted cardboard and any neutralized product were generated as waste, labeled appropriately, and staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-25T15:12:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-21
  • City: ABILENE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LAB experienced a UN1789 Blue Whale Muriatic Acid pH Reducer release from a box containing (2) 1-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of product released to a 4’ x 8’ area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. Two damaged 1-gallon poly jugs were placed into a 5-gallon poly pail. Twelve impacted but not damaged jugs were placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Sodium bicarb was then deployed and utilized to neutralize the impacted areas. All impacted neutralized absorbents and cardboard were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On 3/19/2024, Dangerous Goods Adminstration received a call from Employee 2300567 at the station location in Colorado Springs, reporting a dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of one fiberboard box, containing 3 1-quart plastic bottles labeled "Silver Nitrate". The shipment is discovered damaged from spillage from one of the bottles. The package was not prepared in accordance with IATA Regulations, as it does not have to required markings, labeling, packaging and paperwork. The shipment was placed in a salvage drum and is being held pending an FAA investigation.

item.title: Report E-2024030393
item.description:
Report E-2024030393

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-22T18:13:56+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-13
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 13, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN1903 was damaged by falling freight and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath the trailer. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel utilized hand tools and absorbents to remediate the UN1903-impacted trailer and concrete. All impacted material was collected and containerized into three (3) 35-gallon drums and the patched tote was placed on a spill pallet. All waste was staged in the R+L heat room for transport and disposal. The crew returned the next day to perform a tote transfer. TLE personnel transferred the product from the damaged 330-gallon tote into a new 375-gallon tote to be shipped off to its destination. The generated waste from the transfer was collected and containerized into one (1) 15-gallon poly drum. All waste and the damaged tote was staged in the R+L heat room for transport and disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was unloaded from trailer 828118 that was sent from 774-HOUS-A at 0653. At approximately 0730 package was unloaded from a tugger cart and placed on portable belt at front of belt 1. Belt 1 manager noticed that the item appeared to have some of its contents spill out from its base and called QA to the belt to inspect the package. Upon inspection it was found that the inner item had a damaged base that allowed its contents to spill out. Item was placed in a yellow salvage drum and secured at QA1 to be processed post sort. DescribePack: inner item (plastic pale) cracked at the seam of its base, approximately 7 inches around. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: As soon as the item was confirmed to be damaged it was removed from the belt and placed in a salvage drum then secured at QA1 to minimize the potential for items or personnel being harmed by its contents.

item.title: Report E-2024030373
item.description:
Report E-2024030373

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-21T15:13:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-15
  • City: LANTAU
  • State:
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: AT 14:05 LOCAL TIME IN HONG KONG, AIR PACKAGE 1Z8Y202X0464721146 HAD PASSED X-RAY SCAN WHEN A LOADER OBSERVED THE PACKAGE SMOLDERING ON THE BELT. THIS OCCURRED PRIOR TO LOADING INTO AN AIR CONTAINER. A RESPONDER SEGREGATED AND INSPECTED CONTENTS TO FIND A THERMAL EVENT OCCURRING WITH THIRTEEN OF THE LITHIUM ION BATTERIES INSIDE THE PACKAGE. AT 14:17 LOCAL TIME AIR PACKAGE 1Z8Y202X0466413289 WHICH WAS TRAVELING UNDER THE SAME MULTI-PIECE SHIPMENT WAS FOUND SMOLDERING AFTER HAVING ALREADY BEEN LOADED INTO AN AIR CONTAINER. PACKAGE CONTENTS WERE INSPECTED TO FIND EIGHT LITHIUM ION BATTERIES CHARRED INSIDE THE PACKAGE. LITHIUM ION BATTERIES IN BOTH PACKAGES INVOLVED IN THE THERMAL EVENT WERE ISOLATED. INSPECTION OF THE BATTERIES DO NOT INDICATE THE WATT HOURS. THE THERMAL EVENTS THAT OCCURRED INSIDE BOTH PACKAGES WERE ISOLATED TO THE LITHIUM ION BATTERIES ALONE. THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF CHARRING ON THE OUTER FIBERBOARD BOXES. THE PACKAGES WERE PART OF A 77 MULTI-PIECE SHIPMENT SCHEDULED TO TRAVEL FROM HONG KONG TO THE USA. THE PACKAGES HAD PREVIOUSLY PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT. THE SHIPMENT WAS PREPARED IN ACCORDANCE WITH IATA PI 965 SECTION IA WITH A SHIPPERS DECLARATION, CAO LABELS, CLASS 9 LITHIUM BATTERY LABELS, MARKINGS AND OUTER UN SPECIFICATION PACKAGING. PER 49CFR 171.15, THE INCIDENT WAS REPORTED TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER UNDER REPORT 1393931.

The MNNR refused interchange on the railcar and notified the Union Pacific Railroad of the discovery. The Union Pacific hired Rybak Environmental Inc. to look at the car and clean up the side of the car. Upon inspection by Rybak, it was discovered that the car was missing a manhole gasket.

  • City: BATON ROUGE

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The commodity being shipped are Duracell dry cell batteries. While the shipment is classified as "nonhazard", the shipment began to emit dangerous evolution of heat, triggering an NRC notifciation. On 3/15/2024 at approximately 2200, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 5013755 at the station location in Baton Rouge, reporting a package with a dangerous evolution of heat. The shipment consisted of 12 ‘D’ cell batteries which, after further inspection, appeared to be swollen. During delivery, the driver discovered the package was warm to the touch and returned it to the station. This incident has been to be NRC under Report # 1393991 was generated by Ms. Rawls. Due to the reporting requirements to the NRC, this shipment is also being reported to the FAA and is being held for further disposition instructions.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the paint-impacted floor and swept them in with hand tools. The one (1) damaged 55-gallon metal drum of paint was overpacked into one (1) 85-gallon metal drum for further transport. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum for transport and further handling..

  • Description: On 3/14/2024 at approximately 2158, Dangerous Goods Administation received a call from Employee 240946 at a station location in Spokane, reporting an undeclared deisel spill. The shipment consists of what appears to be a diesel fuel pump containing fuel residue. The shipment was discovered leaking during sort. The package was not prepared in accordance with IATA Regulations, being void of the required markings, labeling, packaging, and paperwork. The shipment is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

item.title: Report E-2024030356
item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-11
  • City: TUCKER
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 11, 2024, two (2) 5-gallon pails of UN2054 were damaged during transit due to lack of dunnage and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the UN2054 impacted trailer floor and neutralized the product on the pallet. FCE deconstructed the pallet and restacked the remaining intact freight for further transport. All spent absorbents and neutralized debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon metal open-top drum for further handling. The two (2) damaged metal pails were placed into one (1) 55-gallon metal open top drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024030498
item.description:
Report E-2024030498

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-28T15:13:06+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-26
  • City: SALT LAKE CITY
  • State: UT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO Logistics
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: It was reported that approximately 5 gallons of KEM 400 Enamel Omaha Orange High Gloss released from a 5-gallon metal pail due to improper loading (it was double stacked, and freight crushed it). The release impacted the trailer floor and one other 5-gallon metal pail of product. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site.

item.title: Report X-2024030550
item.description:
Report X-2024030550

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-27T15:12:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-24
  • City: GEISMAR
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 02-24-2024 a CN transportation employee observed liquid dripping down the side of tank car # UTLX 125078 (Loaded - Spent Sulfuric Acid - UN ID - 1832 - Class 8) while performing switching operations at the CN Geismar Yard located in Geismar, LA. The employee notified the CN Transportation Manager who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team for an emergency response. The responding CN Dangerous Goods Officer performed an inspection of the tank car and noted spillage on the BL side of the car and liquid dripping the eduction line securement flange. Further inspection revealed: (1) of the (4) flange securement fasteners was not properly tightened and could be freely moved by hand. The 1" air valve was in the completely open position with its securement plug securely installed. The 2" liquid eduction line securement cap was less than tool tight (could be turned by hand. The loose liquid eduction line cap was the source of the leak. The tank car's internal pressure was relieved through the 1" air valve stopping the leak. The Liquid eduction line securement cap was properly tightened with an 18" pipe wrench. The 1" air valve was closed, and its securement plug was properly tightened with an 18" pipe wrench. The tank car was then decontaminated by a CN hired contractor. A contractor hired by the responsible party replaced all (4) liquid eduction line flange bolts and securement nuts. The tank car was then pressured up to 10 PSI with a standard air compressor and inspected for leaks. No leaks were discovered.

item.title: Report X-2024030549
item.description:
Report X-2024030549

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-27T15:12:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-22
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Chicago Central and Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 02-22-2024 a CN mechanical performing an inspection observed that the bottom outlet valve appeared to be wet around the valve of tank car # PROX 45654 along with a strong Ethanol type odor in the area. The employee notified the Transportation Manager who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The tank car was set out to an isolation track for inspection by a CN emergency response contractor. A CN emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the location for mitigation. Contractor performed an inspection of the tank car and found the bottom outlet valve to be leaking from the threads of the bottom outlet valve cap as a result of the BOV not creating a proper seal and the BOV cap not tight enough to contain the leak. (The BOV cap was found to be less than tool tight and the BOV valve in the closed position and pinned upon initial inspection). HMR did observe cable seals to be correctly in place. The BOV valve handle was cycled several times to the open and closed position to free any debris that may have been trapped in the BOV sealing surface potentially causing the leak. The BOV cap was then removed and observed for 20 minutes to ensure there was no further leakage from the valve. It was noted that the BOV cap gasket was deformed and was replaced. The bottom outlet valve cap was then re-installed and tightened with a 36" pipe wrench. Upon tightening the BOV cap, Contractor proceeded to place new cable seals on the BOV / Cap.

  • Description: Driver 18151 was dispatched for a load going to Lake Park Mobil but was given a customer information sheet for Northlake Mobil. Driver did not catch this mistake and went to the wrong location. Once he arrived, he obtained an ATG reading that verified his load would not fit. The driver overfilled the tank and this resulted in a spill that impacted a drain. After investigating this with the APEC rep it was determined that the Reg tank was able to hold an additional 200 gallons of regular. Because the tanks are manifolded the rest of the product flowed into the premium tank. Only approximately 12 gallons of product was actually spilled. CDG managed the response and cleanup.

  • Description: RSR Crew was inspecting a set of cars in Silver Springs Siding that NS had set out. Crew noticed car #UTLX 209221 leaking diesel fuel and immediately notified RSR Trainmaster, Matthew Quattrone and Director Environmental Rita Mager. Car UTLX 209221 was set out by NS about 12 hours before RSR crew got there and were not sure how long it had been leaking. It was a slow leak - about 1 drop every 12 to 15 seconds. RSR Crew contained the spill. Rita Mager contacted SPSI who responded to site for repairs to car. Per SPSI, repairs noted as 'Tightened the packing nut of the valve stem packing to stop the leak." Report sent to car owner, who issued the OTMA.

  • Description: Driver pulled into rack to deliver product. While making turn, the driver caught a piece of angled iron from the rack right at the top of compartment #4 of the trailer. He did no realize what had happened and continued to position truck and trailer for delivery. This movement caused a rip in the inner and outer shell of the trailer allowing product to run out of the trailer. The fire dept. was called and they were able to put down booms immediately upon arrival and contain the product to the concrete apron and the oil/water separator/retention area under the trailer. The NRC was called, KY EPA was contacted along with, a spill response team for remediation and clean up. Lewis personnel responded as well to help coordinate delivery of product still in trailer and make sure clean up was done in timely manner.

  • City: PICAYUNE

  • Carrier/Reporter: MC Tank Transport
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: At 2301 ET, MC Tank Transport contacted ERTS to report a release of 5 gallons so far out of a 7000 gallon tank of regulated UN3455 Cresols was released impacting asphalt only no storm drains or waterways were reported to be impacted. ERTS dispatched E3 to the site to perform the clean up and tank transfer. E3 arrived on site and with proper hazmat attire advised an estimated 30 gallons were released to a 8ft by 8ft area of asphalt. E3 contained the spill then conducted the tank transfer, once completed the team will work on the asphalt area. The relief tank and damaged tanker were removed from the site with approval from MS DEQ. The impacted area was scraped with shovels, soda ash was applied to the area and then collected it. There was a second asphalt area impacted that was 3ft x 3ft where the driver entered the property this area was cleaned up. three poly drums of impacted solids were generated and will be staged at 3421 Industrial Rd Pascagoula MS until profiled and properly disposed of.

item.title: Report I-2023120037
item.description:
Report I-2023120037

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-28T00:34:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-11
  • City: ELIZABETH
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Carteret Disposal Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On Thursday, September 7, 2023, Carteret Disposal received a call from a customer, Lind Line, LLC (from Bill LNU), for the delivery of an additional 30 yard container, to their warehouse. Land Line has an arrangement with DNG Transport that they (Land Line) are in charge of ordering containers for the property. DNG Transport is a repeat customer that routinely orders 30 yard containers for what is historically Type-13 waste. Bill requested that the container be placed adjacent to the CDI container that was already on the property. On Friday, September 8th, CDI delivered the container requested, and placed the container were instructed, which was next to the dock door on the property. On Monday, September 11th, Land Line called for a switch of a container, without specifying exactly which container was to be swapped. That evening, a Roll-Off tractor was dispatched to the Land Line address for the switch. The Driver of our Truck informed me that upon arrival, he viewed two containers, one filled 100% with neatly stacked pallets, and another that was approximately only 75% filled with waste. Based on the past practice with this customer, the Driver instinctively removed the container that was 100% filled. Our records indicate that at 8:46 pm, the container was delivered/dumped at the Waste Management, Inc., Front Street facility. The next day, Tuesday, September 12th, I received a call from a manager at the WMI Front Street facility, who indicated that the load from the night before consisted of flammable hand sanitizer, which was prohibited from being accepted at the facility. This was the first that I or anyone else at CDI was advised or made aware of the actual contents of the, container, as we were led to believe that the contents of the container contained exclusively Type-13

  • Description: At approximately 06:15 on June 24th it was reported that a train derailment had occurred on a bridge and there were rail cars in the Yellowstone River. The westbound MLAUMIS1-23 derailed and Bridge 51 near Reed Point, MT failed and it was discovered 1 0 rail cars were in the river. The 10 cars in the river were 6 asphalt, 3 molten Sulphur and 1 loaded car of scrap metal. The cause of the accident is still under investigation.
